fig13-1.caption: Figure 13.1 Waves in the ocean behave similarly to all other types of waves. (Steve Jurveston, Flickr)

fig13-3.caption: Figure 13.3 In this example of a transverse wave, the wave propagates horizontally and the disturbance in the toy spring is in the vertical direction.

fig13-6.caption: Figure 13.6 A surfer negotiates a steep take-off on a winter day in California while his friend watches. (Ljsurf, Wikimedia Commons)

fig13-10.caption: Figure 13.10 These waves result from the superposition of several waves from different sources, producing a complex pattern. (Waterborough, Wikimedia

fig13-11.caption: Figure 13.11 The pure constructive interference of two identical waves produces a wave with twice the amplitude but the same wavelength.

fig13-12.caption: Figure 13.12 The pure destructive interference of two identical waves produces zero amplitude, or complete cancellation.

fig13-16.caption: Figure 13.16 The figure shows a string oscillating with multiple nodes.

fig13-17.caption: Figure 13.17 A wave is inverted after reflection from a fixed end.

fig13-18.caption: Figure 13.18 A wave refracts as it enters a different medium.
